Fig 5 The OER/ORR activities of copper oxyhydroxide series electrocatalysts Yilei Yue Conceptualization Methodology Data curation Writing – original draft Visualization Investigation a Jingjing Niu Data curation Writing – review & editing Visualization b Chengwu Yang Software Writing – review & editing b Jiaqian Qin Supervision b Xinyu Zhang Conceptualization Writing – review & editing Project administration a ⁎ Riping Liu Project administration a a State Key Laboratory of Metastable Materials Science and Technology, Yanshan University, Qinhuangdao 066004, PR China State Key Laboratory of Metastable Materials Science and Technology Yanshan University Qinhuangdao 066004 PR China aState Key Laboratory of Metastable Materials Science and Technology, Yanshan University, Qinhuangdao 066004, PR China b Metallurgy and Materials Science Research Institute, Chulalongkorn University, Bangkok 10330, Thailand Metallurgy and Materials Science Research Institute Chulalongkorn University Bangkok 10330 Thailand bMetallurgy and Materials Science Research Institute, Chulalongkorn University, Bangkok 10330, Thailand ⁎ Corresponding author. Copper oxyhydroxide (CuOOH), an unavoidable oxidic product of CuO and Cu(OH)2 electrocatalysts, is always ignored in water splitting. In this work, we investigated the OER /ORR electrocatalytic activity of all CuOOH series (C2/m, Cmc21, and Pmn21) and proposed an improvement scheme for catalytic activity using the DFT method. The results showed that pure CuOOH matrixes with large OER/ORR overpotentials ( η OER / ORR ) were inert toward OER/ORR. Therefore, eleven metals (Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Zn, Mo, Ru, Rh, Pd, W, and Ir) were used to activate the CuOOH substrates. It is found that the OER/ORR performances of all CuOOH series can be significantly improved by Co or Rh doping. Especially for 2D-layered C2/m-CuOOH substrate, the η OER / ORR was reduced from 1.26 V/2.01 V to 0.25 V/0.22 V and 0.36 V/0.46 V by Co and Rh embedding, respectively, which mainly owes to the regulation from the moderate d-orbital electrons of doped Co and Rh. This work systematically revealed the OER/ORR performance of the CuOOH series, which will promote the development of new catalysts and help us to deeply understand and improve the OER/ORR performance of previous copper oxide electrocatalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords CuOOH catalyst series Co and Rh doping OER/ORR bifunctional electrocatalyst DFT Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction A lot of effort has been put into exploring sustainable development way in the past to address the urgent challenges of the energy and environmental crisis [1,2]. Water splitting has been widely researched as promising hydrogen (hydrogen energy) production method [3–6]. As technology advances, the extensive implementation of electronic equipment and broad advocacy for new energy vehicles also alleviate the pressure of resources and environmental pollution; meanwhile, it means higher requirements for battery performance. Oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) are critical in energy conversion and storage; the chemical activity of material always limits their reaction processes due to their slow kinetics [7–9]. In these cases, abundant efficient OER/ORR catalysts have been developed to address this bottleneck. Costly Pt and RuO2/IrO2 with lower overpotential and Tafel slope reported previously are relatively ideal electrocatalysts for OER/ORR [10–12]. Besides, Pt was handled by nanocrystallizing and alloying technology or formating Pt-rich thin layer on basal material for cost reduction [13–15]. However, developing nonnoble metal catalysts is a basic way to solve the problem of the high cost of the limited application of catalysts. In recent years, graphene has made a big splash in electrocatalytic fields due to its excellent comprehensive properties; a series of excellent catalysts was explored by modifying graphene and graphitic C3N4 (g-C3N4) [16,17]. Chai et al. achieved exceptional ORR and OER bifunctionality in P, N Co-doped graphene frameworks by closely coupled computational design and experimental development [18]. Maryam Jahan even found a composite consisting of graphene oxide (GO) and copper-centered metal-organic framework (MOF), showing high performance as a tri-functional catalyst in HER, OER, and ORR [19]. g-C3N4, a low-cost organic OER electrocatalyst combined with graphene, would become a new catalyst with high OER activity and good durability [20]. Recently, single-atom catalysts [21–23] and MOF catalysts [24,25], as research hotspots, possess the superior intrinsic activity and have developed rapidly. Furthermore, layered hydroxides or oxyhydroxides were also attractive catalyst candidates thanks to their flexible tunability, stability, recyclability, and uniform distribution of metal cations in layers [26–33]. Among all inexpensive electrocatalysts reported before, transition-metal (TM)-based oxides, phosphides, and sulfides have a place in the electrocatalytic field [34,35]. In past years, Copper oxides with high earth abundance, nontoxicity, and accessible synthesis have been exploited as outstanding OER/ORR catalysts by modulating microstructure or combining with others, such as Co-doped CuO nanoarray [36], Cu/(Cu(OH)2 CuO) core/shell nanorods array [37], Ru-doped CuO/MoS2 nanostructures [38], etc. As reported, the Cu2+/Cu3+ redox couple was always identified on CuO or Cu(OH)2-based electrodes in an alkaline solution [39–41]. However, due to the oxidation peak of water-splitting, CuO or Cu(OH)2 oxidized to CuOOH (Cu2+ to Cu3+) could not be observed clearly [40,42,43], which results in ignoration of the effect of CuOOH on the activity of copper oxides electrocatalyst. Therefore, clarifying and modifying the catalytic activity of CuOOH is necessary to improve further and understand the activity of copper oxide-based electrocatalysts towards water-splitting. This work aims to reveal the OER and ORR performance of all kinds of CuOOH (C2/m, Cmc21, and Pmn21) by the first principal method. To further improve performance, we researched metal-modified CuTMOOH (TM = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Zn, Mo, Ru, Rh, Pd, W, and Ir) matrixes. Different catalytic surfaces of two-dimensional layered (2D-L) and block surfaces of three CuOOH bases were explored, respectively. 2D-L C2/m-CuOOH was first investigated to screen active TM elements to modify different catalytic surfaces of other CuOOH (Cmc21, Pmn21). The results showed that although the OER and ORR on pure CuOOH basis surfaces were sluggish, doping Co or Rh could activate all CuOOH series significantly, making them excellent bifunctional catalysts, especially for 2D-L and block C2/m-CuOOH surfaces. The theoretical overpotentials, rate-determining step, and active sites of OER and ORR on the CuTMOOH matrixes were determined and analyzed. Beyond these, the electronic properties of TM d-orbitals were used to explain the mechanism of doping modification. Based on the DFT approach, all CuOOH substrates decorated by Co and Rh show excellent catalytic performance, which implies that CuCoOOH and CuRhOOH may take critical roles in copper oxides electrocatalysts doped by Co and Rh reported before. Our results provide helpful references for exploring new OER/ORR catalysts and studying the activity of copper oxide electrocatalysts toward water-splitting. 2 Computation details All our spin-polarized calculations based on density functional theory (DFT) were carried out within the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) [44,45]. The projector augmented wave (PAW) [46] method was used to describe the core-electron interaction effects, while the exchange-correlation interactions were estimated by Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof (PBE) generalized gradient approximation (GGA) [47,48]. 550 eV plane-wave cutoff energy was adopted in all computations. The Brillouin zone was sampled with 5 × 7 × 1 k-point mesh for the 2 × 2 × 1 C2/m-CuOOH supercell slab, 4 × 6 × 1 k-point mesh for the 2 × 2 × 1 Pmn21-CuOOH supercell slab, and 3 × 6 × 1 k-point mesh for the 2 × 2 × 1 Cmc21-CuOOH supercell slab. A 20 Å vacuum space layer was added to all slab models to avoid periodic structure interaction. All atomic positions of the 2D-L surface and the upper half of the block surface were fully relaxed until the convergence criteria of force and energy reached −0.02 eV Å −1 and 1.0 × 10−5 eV, respectively. The oxygen evolution reactions through the four electron reaction steps generally accepted in the theoretical calculation are as follows: (1) H 2 O + * → OH * + H + + e − (2) O H * → O * + H + + e − (3) H 2 O + O * → OO H * + H + + e − (4) OO H * → * + O 2 + H + + e − where * denotes active sites on the unabsorbed catalyst surface, and OH*, O*, and OOH* are three types of adsorbed intermediates. ORR is carried out through the opposite process of the four reaction equations described above. The free energies of each step were calculated to find the determination step of the whole reaction by the following method: (5) Δ G i = Δ E + Δ ZPE − T Δ S − eU + Δ G pH where Δ E is the reaction energy of each OER/ORR step obtained from formulas in the supplementary information. Δ ZPE is the difference of zero-point energy between the reactant and product molecules absorbed on the CuOOH surfaces, and T Δ S is the product of temperature T and the entropy change Δ S . All calculations were performed at standard conditions ( T = 298 . 15 K , pH = 0 ), and U = 0 . Thus, eU = 0 , the correction of H + free energy Δ G pH = − KTln 10 × pH = 0 . The overpotential of OER and ORR can be determined through the method developed by Nørskov et al. [11]: (6) G OER = max { Δ G 1 , Δ G 2 , Δ G 3 , Δ G 4 } (7) η OER = G OER / e − 1 . 23 (8) G ORR = max { − Δ G 1 , − Δ G 2 , − Δ G 3 , − Δ G 4 } (9) η ORR = G ORR / e + 1 . 23 where Δ G 1 , Δ G 2 , Δ G 3 and Δ G 4 correspond to the free energy of the four OER/ORR reaction steps. η OER and η ORR are overpotentials of the oxygen evolution and reduction occurring on the catalysts surface, respectively. The d-band center theory put forward by Nørskov was used to explain why TM doping can improve electrocatalytic activity, and the following formula can obtain it: (10) ε d c = ∫ − ∞ E f E ρ d ( E ) dE ∫ − ∞ E f ρ d ( E ) dE where E is energy and ρ d is the d orbital DOS. The effect of transition metal doping on the OER activity of the matrix was analyzed by using a descriptor that combines the valence electron in the occupied d-orbital and electronegativity of TM. It can be expressed as follows [49]: (11) φ = θ d × E M + α × n O × E O E O where θ d is valence electron in the occupied d-orbital, E M , E O represent the electronegativity of doped TM and O atoms around TM n O is the number of O atoms, and α as the correction factor is set to 1 in this work. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Calculated models of C2/m, Pmn21, and Cmc21 CuOOH In previous experiments, CuOOH can be obtained by electrodeposition and over-oxidize in a strongly alkaline solution based on the following reaction mechanism [50,51]: Cu + O H − → CuOH + e − , 2 CuOH → C u 2 O + H 2 O + 2 e − , Cu + 2 O H − → CuO + H 2 O + 2 e − C u 2 O + 2 O H − → 2 CuO + H 2 O + 2 e − Cu + 2 O H − → Cu ( OH ) 2 + 2 e − , CuO and Cu(OH)2 were further oxidized to CuOOH, as shown in the following equation: CuO + 2 O H − → CuOOH + e − , CuO + 2 O H − → CuOOH + e − In this work, three kinds of CuOOH basis belonging to the C2/m, Pmn21, and Cmc21 space groups were investigated. As Fig. 1(a) shows, the atomic arrangements in the bulk C2/m and Pmn21 CuOOH lattice are similar and have an obvious layered distribution, so the 2D-L surfaces of these two CuOOH shown in Fig. 1 (c) were constructed for OER/ORR, and the block surfaces of three CuOOH were built. The lattice parameters and cohesive energy ( E c o h ) of all calculated models are listed in Table S1. The negative values of E c o h show that all calculated models have great thermodynamic stability. The density of state (DOS) of three CuOOH is shown in Fig.1 (b). It is found that the sp-d orbital hybridization of three CuOOH bases is close, which means that the introduction of foreign atoms may have similar modification effects on the three substrates. Firstly, we chose the 2D-L C2/m-CuOOH as the representative to find the TM atom, which would further improve the catalytic performance of all CuOOH. 3.2 Eleven TMs decorate 2D-L C2/m-CuOOH matrix The TM-elements doping method is prevailing and efficient in the catalyst field [52–55]. Here, TMs including Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Zn, Mo, Ru, Rh, Pd, W, and Ir usually used to modify electrocatalysts, were selected to decorate the catalyst substrate by replacing a single Cu atom from the top layer of the 2D-L C2/m-CuOOH (−100) surface. As depicted in Fig. 2 (a), two possible reaction sites were considered, i.e., the Cu site and O site on the top layer denoted by the pure-a site and pure-b site in Fig 1. On the (−100) surface of CuTMOOH (TM = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Zn, Mo, Ru, Rh, Pd, W, Ir), three possible reaction sites labeled TM-a site, TM-b site, and TM-c site corresponding to Cu site, O site, and TM site, respectively, were concerned. Observing the thermodynamic reaction free energy of OER/ORR in Fig. 2(b), the obstacle to the OER process on the pure 2D-L C2/m-CuOOH surface is the HOH bond fracture of the H2O molecule, which also limits the hydrogen-proton reducing O2 of the ORR first step. Therefore, we can determine that the corresponding OER/ORR overpotential on the pure C2/m-CuOOH surface is 1.26 V/2.01 V. Then, the catalytic activities of TM-doped CuOOH (−100) surfaces were assessed through the reaction free energy and theoretical overpotential of each OER/ORR step (the details are exhibited in Fig. S1 and Table S3). The results show that the substrates doped with Co, Rh, and Ir have overpotentials lower than those of the others because of the moderate bonding strength between the substrates and the intermediate reactants. According to the equations in the text and the supplementary information (SI), the overpotential is determined by the maximum reaction free energy of all electron-transfer steps, while the reaction free energy depends on the binding energy of the reaction intermediates (OH*, O*, and OOH*). Thus, Fig. 2(c) (volcano plots) builds the relationship between the OER overpotential and the binding energy difference of adsorbates (OOH* and O*). Clearly, on the top of OER volcano, the lower limit η OER = 0.29 V with the optimum binding energy of Δ G OOH * − Δ G O * = ∼1.51 eV divides the plots into two parts. On the positive slope of the volcano ( Δ G OOH * − Δ G O * < 1.51 eV), the OOH* (or OH *) is too strong compared to the binding of O *, implying that the OER rate is limited by the O* formation from OH* (the process of Eq (2)). For the reaction sites distributed on the negative slope of the volcano ( Δ G OOH * − Δ G O * > 1.51 eV), the OOH* binding is too weak relative to that of the O* species, indicating that the formation of OOH* from O* (or the formation of OH *) is the potential determining step. In the strong O* binding regime (negative slope), where most reaction sites scatter, it finds that the | η OER | decreases significantly with the binding strength between O* and substrate weakening. The overpotential order of catalytic sites on various substrates is: pure-b site > Mo-b site > Fe-c site > Ni-b site > Mn-b site > Ru-c site > Ir-c site > Zn-b site (> Rh-c site > Co-c site). These results imply that moderate (not too strong or too weak) bonding strength of adsorbates is more favorable for OER proceeding. It is noteworthy that the optimum binding strength ( Δ G OOH * − Δ G O * = 1.33 eV and 1.00 eV) can be obtained on the Rh-c site and Co-c site, whose η OER are 0.36 V and 0.25 V, respectively. For ORR, the lower limit of η ORR (0.29 eV) with an optimum binding of Δ G OOH * = ∼ 3.98 eV divides the volcano plot of Fig. 2(d) into two parts as well. In the weak OOH* binding regime ( Δ G OOH * > 3.98 eV), the ORR rate limited by hydrogenation of the O2 molecule to OOH* (the process of Eq. (1) in SI), and the η ORR decrease with OOH* binding increase. In the range of strong OOH* binding ( Δ G OOH * < 3.98 eV), the reduction of OH* species into H2O is the potential determining step (the process of Supplementary Eq. 4), and the η ORR decrease as the OOH* binding weaken. Except for the Co-c and Ir-c sites, the rest of the ORR sites distribute along the dashed line of the right volcano plot. The ORR overpotential of the pure 2D-L C2/m-CuOOH substrate ( η ORR = 2.01 V) reduced dramatically by the transition metals embedded. Remarkably, the lowest η ORR = 0.22 V can be achieved at the Co-c site, which is even superior to that of RuO2 and Pt (111) [11,56,57]. The reaction free energy of each OER/ORR step on the Co-c site was exhibited in Fig. 2(e). It shows that the second OER step (OH* → O*) and second ORR step (OOH* → O*) determine η Co OER = 0.25 V and η Co ORR = 0.22 V, respectively. In addition, the OER activity of pristine and doped 2D-L C2/m-CuOOH was visualized using Pourbaix diagrams in Fig. S2 (overpotentials as a function of the solution pH). 3.3 Relationship between overpotential, binding strength, and determining steps The relationship between binding free energies (OH* vs OOH* and O* vs OH *) on various modified 2D-L C2/m-CuOOH surfaces was described In Fig. 3 (a) and (b). The OOH* and OH* species approximately exhibit a scaling relation of Δ G OOH * = 0 . 86 Δ G OH * + 3 . 18 , from which the lower limit of η OER and η ORR in volcano plots above can be obtained. The slope of the fitting line reduces to 0.86 compared with oxides or transition metals [11,58], but with reasonable goodness of fit (R2 = 0.82), and most reaction sites were included in the reign of maximum deviation from liner fit of ±0.3 eV. Therefore, the relationship of Δ G OOH * = 0 . 86 Δ G OH * + 3 . 18 is reasonable for our research objects. As reported before, the slope is related to the valency of the adsorbate [59]. Here, the slop between Δ G OOH * and Δ G OH * close to unity indicates that the charge transfer between TM and adsorbates amounts to approximately 1 e for *OH and *OOH, and reflects the fact that TM binds *OH and *OOH by a single bond, which is consistent with other studies [60]. For the binding free energy of O* species. In Fig. 3(b), it can establish a relationship with OH* species following the equation of Δ G OH * = 0 . 43 Δ G O * + 0 . 57 , whose slope (0.43) is near 0.5 (transition metals) [61], indicating that formal single and double bonds have formated between adsorbates and surfaces. The relatively less correlation between Δ G O * and Δ G OH * because the oxidation state of *O is not always −2. The various oxidation states would make different TM-O bonding strengths and more or less cause the departure from the linear scaling between Δ G O * and Δ G OH * . According to the equation of Δ G OOH * = 0 . 86 Δ G OH * + 3 . 18 , Δ G O * − Δ G OH * and Δ G O * can establish functional relations with the reaction free energy of OER and ORR. Thus, adopting the method reported before [61–63], Δ G O * − Δ G OH * , Δ G O * and overpotential (η) can be used as independent descriptors to fully draw out the reaction steps of OER and ORR in Fig. 3(c) as four zones. The dotted line between every two zones represents the overpotential as a function of the Gibbs free energies of the reaction intermediates, and the calculated details are added in SI. Here, only the most active reaction sites on each surface were compared. In Fig. 3(c), the Co-doped and Rh-doped samples show excellent OER performances owing to their moderate binding strength to adsorbates, which makes the reaction free energy of each step closer to the ideal situation (1.23 eV). However, weak combinations between OH* and substrates, such as Fe, Pd, Ni, Mn, Ir, Zn, Mo, W-doped, and pure 2D-L C2/m-CuOOH, will result in more positive Δ G OH * and larger Δ G 1 , Δ G 3 and η. In the ORR diagram (Fig. 3(d)), comparing Fe, Mn, Ir, Mo, W, Zn-doped and pure substrates, the substrates doped with Co and Rh also possess good ORR activity due to their appropriate Δ G OH * and Δ G O * − Δ G OH * . ORR on Ru-doped surface limited by step 3 (O*→OH*) is due to strong O* binding and weak OH* binding. On the contrary, strong OOH* and weak O* binding determine the ORR overpotential of 2D-L C2/m-CuOOH doped by Ni or Pd. 3.4 The effects of d-band center and descriptor ψ on reaction intermediates On the basis of the above-mentioned results, the OER/ORR overpotential of the substrate is determined by the adsorption free energy of the intermediate. However, doping-TM with different d-orbitals will affect the TM-O bond on the CuTMOOH (−100) surface. In Fig. 4(a) , we find the relationships between adsorption free energies ( Δ G O * , Δ G OH * ) and the d-band center ( ε d c ) [64,65] of doped nonnoble metals (Co, Fe, Ni, Mn, Mo, W, Zn) with the aid of the vaspkit [66] package. The results show that Δ G O * and Δ G OH * reduce with ε d c close to the Fermi level, which dues to the destructive effect of anti-bonding on TM-O bonds are weakened. The *O and *OH adsorptions are enhanced with the TM-O anti-bonding occupancy under the Fermi level decreased, as shown in Fig. 4(c). Additionally, Fig. 4(b) shows the effect of the two most active elements (Rh and Co) on ε d c of 2D-L C2/m-CuOOH, ε d c of pure surface can move from −2.36 to −1.81 eV and −1.66 eV by Rh and Co doping, respectively. Combing with Fig. 4(a) and (c), we can know that Co or Ru doping shifts the ε d c upwards to an appropriate position (compared to Zn and Mn), which makes moderate adsorption ability of substrates to facilitate the OER/ORR process. The calculated values of the d-band center are listed in Table S4. The relationships between the adsorption free energies ( Δ G O * , Δ G OH * ) and the d-band center ( ε d c ) of all doped metals (Co, Fe, Ni, Mn, Mo, W, Zn, Rh, Ru, Pd, Ir) are exhibited in Fig. S3. It is found that there is no explicit change trend for free energy ( Δ G O * , Δ G OH * ) with ε d c increasing in Fig. S3. Moreover, the valence electrons in the occupied d-orbital and the electronegativity of TM can affect the adsorption ability of decorated substrates [49]. Thus, we introduce the descriptor ψ to evaluate this effect (relevant values are listed in Table S5). As Fig. 4(d) and (e) show, the binding strengths of OH* and O* on TM (nonnoble metals)-c sites decrease with ψ growing, which is attributed to more electrons in the d-orbital (a lower d-band center location) of the TM sites will lead to the anti-banding state with higher occupancy under Fermi level, resulting in the weaker adsorption of O* and OH* on surfaces, and vice versa. Unlike O* and OH*, when ψ < 33, the increase ψ corresponds to a strengthening OOH* bond in Fig. 4(f) which demonstrates that the OOH* adsorption is weakened with decreasing electrons in the d-orbital (d-band center moves upwards) of active sites, contrary to the trend of ψ > 33. Maybe it can be explained by the fact that when there are too few electrons in the d-orbital, the binding between TM and OOH* is mainly located near the Fermi level [67]. With the d-band center moving upwards (electrons in the d-orbital decreasing), the TM-OOH* bonding state upshifts as well, which causes the bonding occupancy to decrease, accompanied by OOH* adsorption weakening. The changing trend of binding strengths (OH*, O* and OOH*) on TM (all metals)-c sites with ψ growing was analyzed in the Fig. S4. Compared with the results of nonnoble metals in Fig. 4, the relationship between binding strengths and ψ of all doped metals shows much weaker liner correspondence, which can be reflected by the much lower R2 values in Fig. S4. Additionally, supplementary Fig. S5 provides the charge density difference of active sites for OER in detail. The introduction of foreign elements, represented by Co and Rh, renders more electron shifting from the OH bond to the TM-O bond, making the formation of O* and OOH* more accessible. 3.5 Co and Rh activate Pmn21 and Cmc21 CuOOH series So far, we have known about the modification mechanism of TM elements and screened cobalt and rhodium as the most active elements to modify Pmn21 and Cmc21 CuOOH series next. To evaluate the anchoring capability of the CuOOH to Co and Rh atoms, the binding energy ( E b ) and the dissolution potential U d i s s (vs. SHE) were used to evaluate the thermodynamic and electrochemical stability of embedded elements, respectively. The E b values for the CuTMOOH (TM= Co, Rh) range from −0.76 to −5.08 eV, as listed in Table S6, suggesting that the Co and Rh atoms are firmly anchored onto the CuOOH. Generally, U d i s s > 0 can be adopted as a loose criterion for the electrochemical stability of the compounds [68]. As listed in Table S6, we can see that all of the Co/Rh-doped CuOOH substrates satisfy U d i s s > 0, indicating their electrochemical stability. Considering the similar trend of thermodynamic and electrochemical stability of Co and Rh doped on CuOOH, we chose the CuCoOOH substrates as representatives to further confirm the stability by carrying out ab initio molecular dynamics (MD) simulations at T = 300 K. As Fig. S6 shows, the total energy of the various Co-doped CuOOH substrates oscillating around the equilibrium state verifies their high stabilities. After calculation, it is found that pure substrates of block C2/m-CuOOH, 2D-L Pmn21-CuOOH, block Pmn21-CuOOH and block Cmc21-CuOOH as OER/ORR catalysts were all inert, which explained why CuOOH series was unpopular for water splitting experiments before. As Fig. 5(a) shows, the OER and ORR rates of C2/m and Pmn21 are limited by the weak OH* and OOH* adoption strength resulting η O E R / η O R R =1.98 V/1.96 V for C2/m-CuOOH block surface, η O E R / η O R R =1.92 V/1.95 V for Pmn21-CuOOH block surface, and η O E R / η O R R =1.97 V/1.95 V for Pmn21-CuOOH 2D-L surface, respectively. For C2/m-CuOOH, the OER/ORR overpotential is determined to be 1.68 V/1.42 V by OOH*→O*/OOH*→OH* conversion. According to the catalytic experience of 2D-L C2/m-CuOOH, Co and Rh atoms are the active reaction site for OER/ORR. As Fig. 5 (b) shows, the decorated C2/m, Pmn21, and Cmc21 substrates gather at the volcano map top and have better OER/ORR activity than the pure surfaces at the bottom. The η O E R / η O R R of the C2/m-CuCoOOH block surface displayed in Fig. 5(c) is 0.38 V/0.24 V. Rh doping 2D-L and block Pmn21-CuOOH surfaces have η O E R / η O R R of 0.61 V/0.57 V and 0.39 V/0.54 V. The η O E R / η O R R of Cmc21-CuRhOOH is 0.59 V/0.82 V. More details of intermediates adsorption strength and overpotentials of these doped surfaces are provided in Fig. S7 and Fig. S8. In summary, Co and Rh can activate CuOOH matrixes to be excellent electrocatalysts, although inert CuOOH series as oxidic products of the copper oxides electrode are unfavorable for OER/ORR, which implies that CuOOH can be an accelerator toward water-splitting on the Co/Rh-doped copper oxides electrode reported before [36,38]. From thermodynamics, this work investigated the OER/ORR electrocatalytic activity of all CuOOH series and screened Co and Rh as activated elements for catalytic improvement. In the future, the kinetic effect, solvent effect, and electron correlation effect studies can be carried out further based on our thermodynamic results. 4 Conclusion In summary, we revealed the OER and ORR performance of 2D-L and block surfaces of CuOOH series (C2/m, Cmc21, and Pmn21) and thus obtained a series of bifunctional electrocatalysts based on the DFT method. The pure C2/m, Cmc21, and Pmn21 CuOOH substrates have sluggish OER/ORR activities. Therefore, transition metals Co and Rh were screened out as active elements, which can activate all the CuOOH substrates toward OER/ORR owing to the similar sp-d orbital hybridization in DOS of all CuOOH series. Especially for the 2D-L C2/m-CuCoOOH, the OER/ORR overpotential of the substrate can reach 0.26 V/0.22 V. Closely, the OER/ORR overpotential of Co-doped block C2/m-CuOOH surface is 0.38 V/0.24 V. Regarding the Pmn21-CuOOH system, the η OER / η ORR of 2D-L and block can reduce to 0.61 V/0.57 V and 0.39 V/0.54 V, respectively, after Rh doping. The surface of block Cmc21-CuCoOOH also exhibits good activity with η OER / η ORR = 0.59 V/0.82 V. The above activity improvements of CuOOH substrates mainly derive from the regulation effect of d-band electrons of Co and Rh. In conclusion, our work will be a good reference for future experiments on CuOOH electrocatalysts. Besides, we revealed a possible synergy of TM-doped CuOOH/copper oxides towards water-splitting, which provides a new sight into understanding the activity of copper oxides catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Copper oxyhydroxide (CuOOH), an unavoidable oxidic product of CuO and Cu(OH)2 electrocatalysts, is always ignored in water splitting. In this work, we investigated the OER /ORR electrocatalytic activity of all CuOOH series (C2/m, Cmc21, and Pmn21) and proposed an improvement scheme for catalytic activity using the DFT method. The results showed that pure CuOOH matrixes with large OER/ORR overpotentials ( η OER / ORR ) were inert toward OER/ORR. Therefore, eleven metals (Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Zn, Mo, Ru, Rh, Pd, W, and Ir) were used to activate the CuOOH substrates. It is found that the OER/ORR performances of all CuOOH series can be significantly improved by Co or Rh doping. Especially for 2D-layered C2/m-CuOOH substrate, the η OER / ORR was reduced from 1.26 V/2.01 V to 0.25 V/0.22 V and 0.36 V/0.46 V by Co and Rh embedding, respectively, which mainly owes to the regulation from the moderate d-orbital electrons of doped Co and Rh. This work systematically revealed the OER/ORR performance of the CuOOH series, which will promote the development of new catalysts and help us to deeply understand and improve the OER/ORR performance of previous copper oxide electrocatalysts.
coredata.dc:title: The OER/ORR activities of copper oxyhydroxide series electrocatalysts
